text: <@U0TH5GUQ6|brianbehlendorf> has joined the channel
<@U0ZJZBJLF> I started to prepare the next update to baseimage which includes 1.7, but its not released yet
huh? I saw something was merged
yes, a patch was merged to fabric-baseimage.git, but this is not the same as cutting a release
two extra steps have to happen….a new image is pushed to dockerhub/atlas, and fabric.git is updated to point to it
I’m still working on some kinks in a patch that updates from 14.04 to 16.04
once that is done, ill likely propose a new release
got it.
<@U0ZJZBJLF> i couldn’t gauge your comment: are you for or against upgrading to 1.7?
indifferent... why would I be pro or against?
I mean, I assume they fixed some bugs from 1.6 which is always good
when you said "so it's time to upgrade to 1.7?” I couldn’t tell if you were questioning the wisdom there
I just asked to know if I should also install 1.7 on my VM.
I'm not using the image
oh i see, not yet
I simply install everything manually and if something screams at me I fix it :slightly_smiling_face:
got it…just wanted to make sure you werent objecting
to be honest, I see absolutely no difference
(which is probably more of a good thing than a bad thing)
a colleague of mine mentioned some misbehavior in the `net` regarding DNS resolution in 1.6 that they fixed in 1.7, but I've no idea and didn't take a look what has changed
everything seems to work exactly like it does in 1.6, except the version number is different
ah, cool…i didnt look that deep
only made sure build/unit-test/behave worked
<@U0ZJZBJLF> anyway, to answer your question: monitor this file
<https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/.baseimage-release>
that will tell you when it changes
that was the one i incremented to 1.1 and then it was reverted to 1.0?
oh no
that was in a different path
no, the history has been 0.0.9->0.0.10->0.0.11->0.1.0
but I do have a 0.1.1-snapshot in the baseimage.git tree, perhaps that is what you saw
but like I said, that isnt released yet
(the only real difference between 0.0.11 and 0.1.0 is the method in which it was built
0.0.x was built manually by me on a local machine and pushed out, whereas 0.1.0 was built by jenkins
from there, changes to the baseimage go through gerrit/jenkins, as we saw the recent patches for things like 1.7
what does that mean if someone gives me +1 on gerrit and not +2?
+1 means “LGTM, but someone else needs to approve"
note that non-maintainers can only give -1/0/+1
maintainers can chose -2-+2
so if it was a maintainer +1, they probably felt as though an SME should chime in
(related: -1 means “this cant go in until some changes are made, and -2 means “this shouldn’t go in at all"
SME?
<@U0ZJZBJLF>   SME == Subject Matter Expert

<@U0KPFAZNF> sorry if this question has been asked before, I saw “hyperledger/fabric-baseimage-sandbox” is now published to docker hub, it’s a great enhancement! solves a long-time gnarly error when trying to use docker to set up a network outside of vagrant, where the “network” mode doesn’t work when you try to deploy chaincode, because the hyperledger/fabric-baseimage is missing a bunch of content.
oh, actually thats not what that is for, heh
I just tested pulling the baseimage-sandbox and tag it as baseimage:latest, now everything works like a charm!
that image was created so we could debug our baseimage CI pipeline, it really should go away
but its interesting you were using it like that
yeah that’s why i’m asking
can i count on it being there?
sounds like answer is no :wink:
no, i really should delete it
but lets talk about the real problem
the whole “baseimage:latest” thing has been a source of great confusion, and its in the process of being addressed
so going back to my original requirement: we need to have a way for app developers to set up a local network with docker only (without vagrant)
yep
understood (I actually want the same!)
the short answer is: its not ready for that use case quite yet
the long answer is: being actively worked on
ok great
i hope to have it all squared away in the next few weeks
is the plan to have fabric-baseimage itself be fully built?
(read through your google doc proposal, thought that was the plan…)
(just confirming…)
well, the plan is that “baseimage” will become what it was always intended: a build-time optimization and not a runtime resource
right now, its kind of both
which, as you have discovered, is a problem
going forward, no runtime references to “baseimage” anything will be made
ok, so then for the runtime resource, where peer needs a base image to spin up instances for running chaincode, it’ll ask for a different image?
historically, the primary issue is that chaincode deployment depended on baseimage:latest being present
yep
yes, exactly
ok
so hyperledger/fabric-ccenv will primarily fill this role
ah
but we arent publishing it yet, so it acts kind of like baseimage:latest does
that is, it only works if you build fabric locally
we will be fixing this
i see
theres a new templating engine that is in master
you can get a sense of the direction if you study this:
<https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/peer/core.yaml#L285>
do you have the FAB # for track this handy?
that allows us to, for example, pin the ccenv to the same release as the peer
ok will take a look
its actually pretty close to ready at this point, we just arent pushing the images out yet
I cant recall if there is a FAB, there might be
got it
(sorry, too many balls in the air right now)
couple of caveats: this only applies to master
don’t worry about it then, i assume you’ll send out a notification once it starts publishing...
v0.6 still works with the old system
that’s ok
(and actually, features/* like features/convergence are lagging merges
yeah, ill send out an email/slack when its ready
long story short, right now things only work if you build locally first (unless you hand massage the system)
but soon, it will work in a pure docker flow
perfect
e.g. “docker run hyperledger/fabric-peer” should do everything it needs
btw i also got it working by “make docker-local” from your repo for hyperledger-fabric-baseimage :wink:
most of the major pieces are in place already…biggest challenge is how to sort out the SDK side
yes, though I think all you should really need is “make images” from fabric.git
but i need vagrant for that right?
baseimage building should only be necessary if you are changing the baseimage, or are wanting to support non-x86
you dont need vagrant per se, just an environment capable of supporting the fabric build
if i can run “make images” from fabric without vagrant then i’d definitely do that
remember, fabric.git::master doesnt use baseimage at runtime
ok
but you do need to make sure you have fabric-ccenv
which, building “make images” will get you that
cool
plus building the baseimage is sloooooowww
:wink:
so youll be happy to avoid that
(yes very slow)
thanks for all this, very nice work!
ty, ill hopefully have something that satisfies your usecase soon
<@U13TWBRBL> btw: vagrant is much lighter weight to stand up now
not sure why you are avoiding it, but if it was because the provisioning was slow, that is fixed in master
it takes about 60-90 seconds to stand up
what?! you serious?
yeah
try it :slightly_smiling_face:
what did you do?
bunch of stuff, the biggest was that I moved almost everything into the baseimage
you wanna tell me i do git clone and then vagrant up and it takes 90 sec? not a chance
so its all installed already before you even type “vagrant up"
sounds sci-fi
it does for me, and I am on a 2011 laptop
I'm on a 2017
nice!
I'll try and check
one caveat, the baseimage.box has to be downloaded the first time
so first boot will be slightly slower
depending on your internet speed
so 60-90 is assuming you have the image already
but it gets cached, so its pretty good for subsequent builds
just ran one

real	1m37.301s
user	0m5.094s
sys	0m2.481s

<@U0KPFAZNF> good to know about the vagrant speed up, I’m sure it’ll help many peer contributors. from my standpoint, I have two hats: 1) node.js SDK contributor, 2) advocate for good experience for application (including chaincode and app dev) developers. for both of my roles, I’d like to avoid vagrant since a docker-based set up is more standard in the node.js world
yeah, though I am not convinced a docker based flow is good for peer/ca development
it goes against the grain on docker to use it that way
i think it makes a ton of sense for _runtime_ though
e.g. I just want to “docker run …-peer” to stand it up
as far as having all the tooling you need to compile it, etc, not sure it makes as much sense, and vagrant is a good fit there
so, i see both as continuing to have a role going forward
yes, we are agreeing. i was also saying vagrant is good for peer/ca contributors.
right ok
node.js SDK is now a standalone project, separated from fabric
is that completed now?
i saw it was being broken out
im glad to see the separation, btw
i think we need to break out the shims too
not yet complete in that we don’t have it integrated in the CI process yet
right ok
agreed re: breaking out shims. do you know who’s working on that?
I dont even know _if_ someone is working on that
i just think it needs to be done
oh ok
btw: I removed the -sandbox image :wink:
sorry if that was helpful, but it was never intended in that role
ok
no worries. glad I checked with you
quick question:

jimzhang:fabric jimzhang$ make images
Building docker src-image
docker build -t hyperledger/fabric-src build/image/src
Sending build context to Docker daemon 11.55 MB
Step 1 : FROM hyperledger/fabric-baseimage:x86_64-0.1.0
x86_64-0.1.0: Pulling from hyperledger/fabric-baseimage
862a3e9af0ae: Already exists 
6498e51874bf: Already exists 
159ebdd1959b: Already exists 
0fdbedd3771a: Already exists 
7a1f7116d1e3: Already exists 
0620a24d487d: Pull complete 
b46385a2c430: Pull complete 
Digest: sha256:ac6a2784cfd028ae62f5688f4436f95d7a60eeacd8506eb303c9c6335328c388

 ---> db53d04b117c
Step 2 : ADD gopath.tar.bz2 $GOPATH/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric
Error processing tar file(bzip2 data invalid: bad magic value in continuation file): 
make: *** [build/image/src/.dummy] Error 1
building this in my mac environment, any idea what might have caused the error?
guess i need to install a bzip2 handler?
no idea, sorry
never seen that before
very odd though, i would expect bzip2 schema to be fairly ubiquitous at this point
have to step out for a bit
bbiab
wow, it took me a few seconds
<@U0ZJZBJLF> so if I “vagrant destroy” and then “vagrant up”, it'll only take a few seconds?
Dunno, depends on your computer
guess i’ll try that to find out

<@U0KPFAZNF> do you know what it takes to get the fabric-starter-kit image published to docker hub? is it a new jenkins job? is the account credentials part of the jenkins env variable? just wondering if I could ask one of my colleagues (like Ramesh) to help us with this...
It takes 1m37s on my 2011 MacBook Pro
Ramesh needs to add it to ci-management.git and I need to create the repo for it on dockerhub
I'll do that shortly
We don't need a new job, just augment to one that pushed peer/ca
Sorry for typos, on mobile
<@U13TWBRBL> I created this: <https://hub.docker.com/r/hyperledger/fabric-starter-kit/>

<@U11HH3P7Y> will need to augment the list here: <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/gitweb?p=ci-management.git;a=blob;f=jjb/fabric/include-raw-docker-image-deploy.sh;h=35ad0a282a4dc27a207591bd1013bf02eb647426;hb=HEAD>
probably should drop the :latest tag, too
actually this whole thing might need review:  not sure the $BRANCH is relevant any more either
<@U13TWBRBL>: we need a new job to test changes on fabric-starter-kit
Please let me know what tests you want to keep in new Jenkins job
<@U0KPFAZNF>: thanks!
<@U11HH3P7Y>: I guess for tests just a simple validation of a bash command to launch the sample app (which executes a main() and exits) should be sufficient
Trick is it needs the peer and membersrvc images to be running to execute. <@U1KFBBWG1> should have more details
<@U1KFBBWG1|harrisob> has joined the channel
ok will check with him
thanks
<@U2A5NPBQ9|kent_landholm> has joined the channel
